What happens if a UN Security Council resolution is violated? UN Security Council resolutions ARE binding (contrary to what the US is saying). Israel breached the ceasefire resolution within hours, and last night bombarded Gaza again. Chapter VII of the UN Charter states: Article 41 The Security Council may decide what measures not involving the use of armed force are to be employed to give effect to its decisions, and it may call upon the Members of the United Nations to apply such measures. These may include complete or partial interruption of economic relations and of rail, sea, air, postal, telegraphic, radio, and other means of communication, and the severance of diplomatic relations. Article 42 Should the Security Council consider that measures provided for in Article 41 would be inadequate or have proved to be inadequate, it may take such action by air, sea, or land forces as may be necessary to maintain or restore international peace and security. Such action may include demonstrations, blockade, and other operations by air, sea, or land forces of Members of the United Nations. So first start is sanctions. The Security Council is no stranger to imposing sanctions. Since 1966, the Security Council has established 31 sanctions regimes, in Southern Rhodesia, South Africa, the Former Yugoslavia (2), Haiti (2), Angola, Liberia (3), Eritrea/Ethiopia, Rwanda, Sierra Leone, Côte d’Ivoire, Iran, Somalia/Eritrea, ISIL (Da’esh) and Al-Qaida, Iraq (2), Democratic Republic of the Congo, Sudan, Lebanon, Democratic People’s Republic of Korea, Libya (2), the Taliban, Guinea-Bissau, Central African Republic, Yemen, South Sudan and Mali. In 2022, the UNSC tried imposing sanctions on Russia for its invasion of Ukraine. But Russia being an SC permanent member, vetoed it. So the resolution was not passed, but this did not stop Western countries (and many others) imposing sanctions on Russia. So there's a precedent. Even if US vetoes any sanctions resolution, other member states can and should (to honour international law) sanction Israel. States can sanction fully or partially. Yesterday 120 UK MPs wrote to David Cameron (Foreign Secretary) to ban UK arms sales to Israel - which includes parts of fighter jets and missiles. The UK government can do this immediately. Start with this. This belongs on LinkedIn because a few of us will soon issue a note to Corporate Compliance and Risk teams. It's on companies to ensure they are not in any way complicit in a genocide (note the UN has just confirmed this IS a genocide).

The indiscriminate massacre by the terrorist group Hamas is unfathomable, and the barbaric killing of innocent Israeli lives cannot be justified as an argument to the apartheid decades of blockade the Palestinians have endured. The ongoing bombardment by the IDF has wreaked an insurmountable havoc across swaths of Gaza. As the world mourns and sympathies the loss of innocent Israeli lives, thousands of Gazan families are destroyed. In the end, this will not be the end. The ongoing slaughter at the hands of the IDF will, unfortunately and gravely, have ripple effect across the world. Communities of all, from the developed to the developing world will come to face with the wrath unleashed as a result of these two factions in the Middle East. From places of tourism, public servicing places, health institutions, even sleepy heartland community gathering places will not be spared. Satellite Islamic extremist groups will take this opportunity to strike fear into the hearts, regardless of faith and beliefs, or the absence of it. Alike, white-supremacists and right-wing radical groups will target places of worship. No country can stay neutral as such events are unfolding. The war might be between Israel and Hamas, but the effects will be felt by everyone in this world. #worldpeace #worldinpieces #insolidarity
